A basic_face_identification is a type of that is for the identification of the face of a solid shape. The identified face has been created by a construction operation. The attribute containing_model represents a solid shape containing the face after the construction operation.
Most of construction operations are defined in the solid_shape_element_schema of ISO 10303-111, some operations are defined in the geometric_model_schema of ISO 10303-42.
The attribute containing_model will be redefined in the subtype entities to restrict the usage of the entities to the certain construction operations defined in ISO 10303-42 or ISO 10303-111.

An imported_face_identification is a type of that specifies a face in an imported B-rep model. The imported_face_identification has attributes which directly reference an instance of and an instance of a which contains that surface.
Typical design process often starts from an existing B-rep model that has no construction history. Users import the existing B-rep model and start modelling using CAD systems. Therefore, it is required to identify shape elements such as faces, edges, and vertices in the imported B-rep model to apply further construction operations to the solid.
If it is required to identify a particular edge or vertex of an imported B-rep model this can be done by using the entities or from this part of ISO 10303 together with appropriate instances of imported_face_identification to identify the adjacent faces.

A profile_based_feature_identification is a type of that specifies a face relating to a profile based feature.
A solid created from profile based feature has only one initial and terminal face. All the instances of edge_segment in the surface_instance contribute to the creation of lateral faces of a solid. Therefore, the attribute itself is enough to identify an initial or a terminal face. The other attributes surface_instance and edge_segment become null value for initial and terminal faces.
The profile based features can be classified into additive and subtractive features in terms of the difference between the volume of the original solid and that of the resulting solid. This entity is intended for the identification of both additive and subtractive profile based features.
the instance of a that specifies a profile or a defining the surface to be swept;
the segment of the boundary which, in the case of lateral faces, determines the identified face;
the creation type of a face comprising a profile based feature.

A revolved_hole_feature_identification is a type of that specifies a face relating to a hole feature such as in ISO 10303-111.
In Figure 6, the face 1 is a lateral face and it can be therefore identified by , , and edge_list[4] as an . The face 2 can also be identified by , , and edge_list[1] as an similar with the face 1.
In typical CAD systems, the system requires a centre point, radius, and depth for a simple hole as shown in Figure 6. Then, the system would create a hole as a revolved solid with a sketch and an axis for the revolution. Therefore, the face identification of a hole feature can be treated the same as the face identification of a revolve feature.

A transition_feature_identification is a type of that specifies a face relating to a transition feature such as edge blend and chamfer. Transition features are usually applied to an existing solid body. Therefore, the existing face identifications are used for the identification of a newly generated face created from a transition feature.

Therefore, the face identification of the replicated solid is based on the face identification of the existing solid, and additional order information is added to differentiate the replicas.

ext_description.p: An ambiguity_resolution specifies the information needed to resolve the ambiguity between the topological entities having the same basic identification in the old model (pre-edit model) and new model (post-edit model). There are two types of ambiguity to be resolved, one is when faces are split, and the other is when faces are merged.

A split_element_information is a type of and of that specifies the SEI to resolve the ambiguity when element split occurs. The SEIs of split elements are determined by calculating x, y, and z values of reference points on the split elements in the object space and then assigning priorities, or element_order to the split elements. The object space is the local 3D Cartesian coordinate space of the form feature.

For the calculation of SEIs, it is required to determine reference points of the topological entities having the same identifications in the following manner. Reference points of two topological entities that may cause ambiguity must be different [4]. Suppose A and B are split faces as illustrated in Figure 18. Firstly, axis-aligned bounding boxes for A, B are generated. Then, all the boundary lines of the smaller bounding box are extended. If there is no intersection between extended lines and the other face, any points in A and B can be selected as illustrated in Figure 18 (a). If there is an intersection between the extended lines of A and face B, one of the intersecting points should be selected as illustrated in Figure 18 (b). If there are intersections in many directions, extended lines parallel to x axis have the first priority, and extended lines parallel to y axis have the second priority, and extended lines parallel to z axis have the last priority. If there are multiple intersections in one direction, all the intersecting points will be compared by their coordinates. For the comparison of coordinates, x precedes y and y precedes z, and a point with the smallest value will be selected. In Figure 19, split_elements_number becomes 2, and the element_order of face 2 and face 3 become 1 and 2 respectively.

A merged_element_information is a type of and of that specifies the MEI to resolve the ambiguity when elements are merged to other element. The basic identification of merged element is defined by listing the identifications of the elements which are merged [5].
Figure 20 illustrates the way to specify MEI in case of merged face. The face 1 is merged with face 2. In terms of face1, therefore, merged_elements_number becomes 1 and merged_element_identifications is the identification of the face 2.

A topology_based_element_identification is a type of that specifies the identifications of topological elements such as face, edge, and vertex, which are represented by their topological information.

A topology_based_face_identification is a type of that represents the identification of a face entity based on its topological information. A face can be created by a construction operation, and also can be split and merged during the design process. Therefore, the face can be identified by its face_basic_identification as well as face_SEI and face_MFI.
the basic identification of the given face;
the split element information of the face;
the merged element information of the face.

A topology_based_edge_identification is a type of that represents the identification of an edge entity based on its topological information. An edge can be identified by of two adjacent faces and edge_SEI.
In Figure 21, edge 1 and edge 2 have the same two adjacent faces. Therefore, the use of an appropriate reference point is required to identify the particular edge as a split element information.
A case for split element information of edges
the identification of the adjacent face to the left of the edge;
the identification of the adjacent face to the right of the edge;
the split element information of the edge.

A topology_based_vertex_identification is a type of that represents the identification of a vertex entity based on its topological information. A vertex can be identified by the list of of adjacent faces and vertex_SEI.
In Figure 22, vertex 1 and vertex 2 have the same adjacent faces which are face 1, face 2, and face 3. Therefore, the use of an appropriate reference point is required to identify the particular vertex as a split element information. In this case, x, y, and z coordinates of a vertex become a reference point.
In general cases, a vertex has three or more adjacent faces. In case of a cone, however, the apex of a cone has just one adjacent face. Therefore, the minimum number of adjacent_faces becomes one.
A case for split element information of vertices
the identifications of the adjacent faces to the vertex;
the split element information of the vertex.

A user_selected_topology_element is a type of in ISO 10303-42 represents an element selected via its persistent identification in the procedural shape modelling.
A user_selected_topology_element instance can be an element in a set of instances defined in the attribute of the entity in ISO 10303-55 [2].
This entity user_selected_topology_element is to select an element which is topologically identified by this part of ISO 10303, whereas selects an element geometrically from the users view point. If a model is procedurally created by construction operations from scratch and all the elements comprising the model can be therefore topologically identified, can be substituted for user_selected_topology_element for selecting an element. In other words, both entities can be interchangeably used.
the unique identification of the topological entity which is being selected.

The boolean function face_in_brep accepts as input a and a and returns true if the face is one of the faces used to define the shells of the B-rep. The function first uses the function to construct the set of all the shells of the B-rep. For each shell of this set it uses the function to construct a list of faces, each face in the list is compared to the input test_face and, if identical the function returns TRUE. If no match is found after all faces of all shells have been tested the function returns FALSE.
The functions and are defined in ISO 10303-42.
